His dream is to improve his and his family's quality of life.  He has always wanted to give them something different.  This motivates him to work with greater enthusiasm, since work alone will succeed in giving his family what they desire so much.

It is for these reasons that he has made the decision to become involved with the organization INTEGRAL: to ask for this loan which will allow him to invest in farming supplies such as seeds, fertilizer, and insecticide, among other things.  He hopes to accomplish his objective of giving his family what they deserve and being able to attain a better quality of life.

loans.use: invest in farming supplies, such as seeds, fertilizer, insecticide, etc.

loans.name: Juan Andres

texts.es: Juan Andrés vive junto a su compañera de vida y sus hijos en casa propia; él se dedica a la  venta de ropa para damas, caballeros y niños,  posee en variedad camisas, faldas, vestidos, pantalones entre otros con todas las tallas y con ropa muy novedosa, tiene varios años con el negocio y eso le ha regalado mucha experiencia que le permite obtener las mejores ganancias; comercia de forma ambulante y desde su hogar, se ha hecho de mucha clientela pues las personas la prefieren porque siempre tiene lo que necesitan a precios accesibles, con producto de calidad y con un servicio excelente; Juan es un hombre emprendedor y muy dedicado a su labor, siempre esta luchando por lo que desea y no piensa rendirse hasta alcanzar el éxito que se merece, en los últimos meses incremento la venta y quiere aprovechar para realizar una nueva inversión, pero no posee de capital que lo respalde por eso le solicita a INTEGRAL un crédito que le permita comprar ropa por mayor. Juan Andrés tiene buenas referencias de pago y es muy responsable asegura que podrá saldar la deuda y a la vez tiene fe que le llevara a su hogar seguridad económica.
texts.en:
Juan Andrés lives with his partner in their own house.  He works in the sale of clothing for women, men, and children.  He has a variety of shirts, skirts, dresses, and pants (among other things) of all sizes that are very fashionable.  He has been with this business for several years, which has given him a lot of experience that helps him obtain the best profits.  

He sells as a street vendor and from his home.  He has obtained many customers because people prefer him, since he always has what they need at reasonable prices and good quality, along with excellent service.  

Juan is a very enterprising man and is very dedicated to his work.  He is always striving for what he wants and never things of giving up until he reaches the success that he deserves.

In recent months, sales have increased and he wants to take advantage of it in order to make a new investment, but he doesn't have the resources to back it up.  Because of this, he is asking INTEGRAL for a loan to allow him to buy wholesale clothes.

Juan Andrés has good payment references and is very responsible.  He guarantees that he will be able to pay back his debt and at the same time has faith that it will bring financial stability to his home.

loans.use: buy wholesale clothes

loans.name: Tuychiboy

texts.ru:
Туйчибой 34-летний мужчина, отец троих детей, занимается откормом и разведением скота. С детства он помогал отцу ухаживать за скотом, теперь сам продолжает работу отца. Жена его поддерживает и в его отсутствие присматривает за скотом. Развивая этот бизнес и имея хороший доход они недавно построили дом чему очень рады. Туйчибой планирует увеличить поголовье скота  и теперь на сумму дохода хочет  купить грузовую машину.  Это машина ему очень необходима для перевозки скота. Каждую неделю он ходит в скотный базар, продает откормленных овец и взамен покупает молодых овечек. 
На полученный кредит Туйчибой хочет купить несколько овец и откормив их до весны планирует продать по дороже и надеется получить хорошую прибиль и осуществить свои планы. Заранее благодарит организацию Кива за поддержку.
texts.en: Tuychiboy is a 34 year old man, he is a father of three children and does feeding and breeding of cattle. He has helped his father to take care of the cattle since childhood and now continues to do father's work. His wife supports him and looks after the cattle when he is absent. By growing their business and having a good income they have recently built a house which they are very happy about. Tuychiboy plans to increase the headcount of cattle and wants to use the profit amount to buy a gas vehicle. This vehicle is very needed to transport the cattle. He goes to the cattle market every week where he sells the fed sheep and in return buys young ones. Tuychiboy wants to use the loan to buy several sheep and plans to sell them at a higher price before the spring and hopes to receive a good profit and realize his plans. He is thanking Kiva for the support in advance.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Dubis

texts.es: Dubis vive con sus 3 hijos, de 7 a 15 años, al suroccidente de la ciudad. Allí se dedican a la venta de mercancía variada, especialmente de ropa interior, multiusos, suéteres y bermudas. Su negocio inició desde hace 5 años, cuando para sentirse activa, agregar ingresos a su hogar, para responder mas efectivamente  a sus necesidades, decidió apoyar la gestión de su cónyuge, quien trabaja como contratista de una importante empresa. Así fue como Dubis organizó en su domicilio un espacio donde ofrecer los artículos para la venta de contado, el cual aun abre sus puertas desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 8 de la noche. . Sus compras las realiza de contado y muchas veces a crédito, a proveedores del centro de la ciudad, que están instalados en zonas comerciales muy conocidas por los comerciantes. Mas adelante su meta es tener su casa propia, pues vive en casa familiar y este es uno de sus mayores desafío. En la actualidad, está aplicando a un  credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará ropa interior y exterior muy variada y colorida, con ello planea impactar a su clientela en la temporada de carnaval que se aproxima y es una de las mas comerciales de la temporada que fortalece la dinámica económica de muchos pequeños comerciantes del departamento del Atlántico.
texts.en: Dubis lives with her 3 children, ranging from 7 to 15, in the southwestern part of the city. They sell various merchandise, especially underwear, shirts, sweaters and bermuda shorts.  She started her business 5 years ago, when, in order to feel active, add income to the home, and respond effectively to her need, she decided to help her spouse, who works as a contractor at an important business. That's how Dubis organized a space in her home where she offers the items she sells for cash up front. She opens her doors from 8 in the morning until 8 at night. She does her buying in cash or many times on credit, from suppliers in the center of town who are set up in commercial areas that merchants know very well. In the future, her goal is town her own home because she lives in a family home and it is one of her biggest challenges. Right now, she is applying for a Kiva loan, the first loan she has taken out with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. With it, she will buy various underwear and other clothing. With it, she plans on impacting her clientele during the carnival season which is coming up and it is one of the most commercial times that fortifies the economic dynamic of many small businesses in the  Atlántico department.

loans.use: to buy a wide variety of underwear and other clothing.

loans.name: Silvia

texts.es: Silvia vive con su cónyuge y es madre de 3 hijos mayores de edad. Ella cuando trabajaba en una empresa donde fabricaban productos de confecciones, aprendió todo lo que hoy sabe hacer, y por eso se dedicó a ello, generando sus propios ingresos  para que su hogar gozara de más bienestar. Su negocio desde hace 7 años inició y hasta ahora ha mostrado crecimiento, pero no suficiente como el que ella aspira; en su proceso productivo, trabaja las operaciones de corte confección, relleno y armado, porque sus principales líneas de productos son los forros de colchones, almohadas, sabanas y cortinas. Su actividad la inicia desde las 6 de la mañana hasta las 8 de la noche  y sus transacciones comerciales las realiza con los hoteles, clínicas, residencias; ella compra sus  materias primas e insumos en almacenes del centro de la ciudad, en la modalidad de contado. En la actualidad está aplicando a un  credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará telas, correderas, hilos, fibras, espumas, impermeables y cueros. Sus productos de lencería además de ser útiles en el mercado, llenan las expectativas de calidad que esperan sus compradores, por eso sus metas principales están encaminadas a hacer crecer su negocio, porque son muchos los clientes que le solicitan artículos, pero su capital de trabajo es insuficiente para responder a su propósito de ampliación.  Su meta mas adelante está encaminada a adicionar mayor infraestructura de maquinarias porque al futuro, quiere comprar una casa y tener un vehículo para transportarse, mientras esto ocurre, Silvia se esmera en contactar muchos mas clientes  que contribuyan al incremento de sus ventas, para día a día ganar mucho mas posición en el mercado cambiante.
texts.en: Silvia lives with her spouse and is the mother of 3 grown children. When she used to work for a person when they made sewed products, she learned everything that she needs to know now. That is why she works doing this now, generating her own income so her family can be better off. She started her business more than 7 years ago and so far, it has grown, but not as much as she aspires to. In her productive process, she cuts and sews, fills and reinforces, because her main products are mattress covers, pillows, sheets and curtains. She starts her activity at six in the morning and works until 8 at night. She does her business in hotels, clinics, and residences. She buys her raw materials in stores in the center of town and pays upfront. Right now, she is applying for a Kiva loan, the first loan she has taken out from the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. With it, she will buy fabrics, runners, thread, fibers, foam, waterproof fabric and leathers. Her lingerie products are also useful in the market and fulfill her buyers; expectations of quality. That is why her main goals are oriented towards making her business grow, because a lot of customers ask her for items. However, her working capital is not enough to respond to her purposes of growth. Her goal for the future is it add better infrastructure with her machines. In the future, she wants to buy a house and have a vehicle to get around in and contact many more customers who will contribute to an increase in sales so she can make more day to day with a much better position in the changing market.

loans.use: to buy fabrics, runners, threads, fibers, foams, waterproof fabrics and leather.

loans.name: Elinette

texts.en:
Elinette, 42 years old, is married to a personal driver. They are currently residing in the village of Culing Centro with their two children. Elinette has owned and operated a retail store for almost 11 years, and with this business she earns a net income amounting to approximately Php 5,000 every month.

She is requesting a loan of Php 25,000 to purchase breads, canned goods, noodles, biscuits, and beverages. She also has a livestock business, raising some hogs and chickens for an additional source of income. She's hoping that her requested loan will be granted so that her business will become more profitable.

loans.use: To purchase breads, canned goods, noodles, biscuits, and beverages.

loans.name: Larra

texts.en:
Larra is 24 years old, married, and has two children. She is cooking and selling snack foods for income. She patiently attends to her customers needs, even though she generates only minimal income from it. 

Her children are in school and she wants to give them the best education. Maintaining good sales and income from her small business will help educate her children. So, Larra is asking for a loan of P6,000 to buy hotdogs, fish balls and eggs to cook and sell. It will help increase her sales volume.

loans.use: to buy hotdogs, fish balls and eggs to cook and sell.

loans.name: Lorgina

texts.en:
Lorgina is a merchant from the province of Bohol, Philippines. She is married and has two young children. She runs a sari-sari or variety store business and has been in the business for more than nine years now. Her husband works as a carpenter.

Lorgina is applying for a loan of 12,000PHP to buy additional merchandise to sell, like rice, soda, canned goods, noodles, toiletries and others. Lorgina is optimistic that this loan could help her in improving her business.

loans.use: to buy additional merchandise to sell like rice, soda, canned goods, noodles, toiletries and others.

loans.name: Diana Lissette

texts.es: Diana Lissette vive junto a su pequeña familia, ella posee una sala de belleza realiza cortes, planchados, maquillaje, entre otros siempre con estilo y a la vanguardia para que los clientes queden satisfechos, tiene varios años con el negocio y eso le ha regalado mucha experiencia en la venta que le permite obtener las mejores ganancias, su negocio esta ubicado en un lugar que califico que muy bueno para su actividad laboral, es muy conocido por las personas de la comunidad donde viven,  tiene mucha clientela y la prefieren por la calidad, los buenos  precios y sobre todo por  un buen servicio; Diana es una mujer emprendedora, dedicada a  su labor y con muchas ganas de salir adelante y cumplir sus sueños ,  todos los días trabaja duro para poder alcanzar el éxito y no piensa flaquear al estar frente alguna dificultad es muy determinante, quiere acrecentar el negocio y para ello necesita de capital que la respalde por eso le solicita a INTEGRAL un crédito que le permita comprar plancha, secadora, tijeras, etc. Diana Lissette tiene buenas referencias de pago y una moral intachable, asegura que podrá saldar la deuda y  la vez confía que le dará a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Diana Lissette lives with her small family. She owns a beauty salon where she offers services like haircutting, hair ironing and makeup, always with style and following the latest trends in order to satisfy her clients. Diana has had this line of work for several years, which has given her a lot of experience in sales, so she is making good profits. Her salon is located in a place that she describes as good for her business, since it is well-known by the local people. She has a good client base; they choose her because of the good quality, good prices and the good service she provides.

Diana is an enterprising woman, focused on her job and with a strong will to get ahead in life and make her dreams come true. She works hard every day in order to succeed and is not thinking on quitting even when difficulties arise. Diana wants to expand her business, so she needs some capital to support her plans. This is why she is requesting a loan at INTEGRAL to buy a hair iron, a hair dryer, and scissors, among other supplies she needs.

Diana Lissette has a good financial record and impeccable morals. She promises to repay the debt and trusts that this will be an opportunity to give her family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy a hair iron, a hair dryer and scissors, among other things.

loans.name: Rano

texts.en:
Rano is a very kind and successful lady. She is 28 years old. Rano is not married and lives with her parents. She is a doctor. She has worked at the hospital in her region for more than 3 years. She is a therapist and knows her function very well. She likes her profession and works with pleasure. She takes care of ill people perfectly. 

Rano tries to improve her knowledge and that’s why she entered a Traineeship at Tajikistan Medical University. She must pay for her tuition, but her salary is small and she does not have enough money. She is asking for a loan to pay her tuition. She awaits your support.

loans.use: To pay her tuition.

loans.name: Xerses

texts.en:
Xerses lives peacefully in Solana with his spouse and child. Xerses is 33 years old. His wife is a day care worker while he sells and distributes soft drinks to stores in their village and nearby communities. He uses his motorcycle to transport his products. He has been doing it for four years now. He usually gains about PHP 8,000 each month and it goes on the family's sustenance. He also uses another part of his income as revolving capital. 

He would like to increase his profits that is why he is asking for a loan of PHP 20,000 to buy cases of soft drinks to sell. It will help increase his sales capacity and income as well. Xerses hopes to keep extending his good services to his customers and become a sucessful entreprenuer for the overall welfare of his family.

loans.use: to buy cases of soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Ma. Christy

texts.en:
Ma. Christy is a married woman and a mother of two young children from Bohol, Philippines. She and her husband have been engaged in a fishing business for more than three years now.

Ma. Christy is asking for a loan to buy new fishing nets, lead weights and hooks. With this, her husband will be able to catch more fish thus giving them more to sell in the market. Ma. Christy dreams of making their fishing business a success and saving money for the future schooling of their children.

loans.use: to buy new fishing nets, lead weights and hooks.

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Christina works hard to support her family. Christina is married and has a food processing business in the Philippines.

Christina requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business.

Christina has been in this business for seven years now and is still working hard to develop her business.

In the future, Christina would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Tolotea

texts.en:
Tolotea is a 28-year-old married woman with two children. She has a small plantation and grows yam, taro etc. to earn a living. She has been doing this for six years.

Tolotea has requested a loan to improve her home conditions and buy new equipment for her business. Tolotea joined SPBD in 2011. Tolotea wishes to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, a shovel, weed killer, bush knives and wheel knives.

loans.name: Book Guis- Guis Group

texts.fr:
L e groupe de crédit Book Guis Guis regroupe cinq personnes qui vivent dans le même quartier et ont des liens de parenté. Ils ont à leur tête un homme qui s’appelle Amet et est âgé de 51 ans, père de 3 enfants. Il commence sa journée à 7h pour la terminer à 15h. Monsieur Amet fait de la vente de vaisselles depuis longtemps maintenant et il souhaite renforcer son fond avec l’argent du crédit. C’est avec les bénéfices de son activité qu’il réussi à entretenir sa petite famille.
 Il désire un jour, avoir son autonomie et ne plus recourir aux prêts.
texts.en: The loan group Book Guis Guis groups together 5 people who live in the same district and are related. Their leader is a man called Amet who is 51 years old and the father of 3 children. He starts his workday at 7 o'clock in the morning and ends at 3 o'clock in the afternoon. Amet has been selling crockery for a long time now, and wants to strengthen his inventory with the loan money. It is the profits generated by his business that enable him to take care of his little family. He would like one day to be self-sufficient and no longer have to resort to loans.

loans.use: to buy crockery for resale.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia, 50 years old, is married to a driver and blessed with two children. They are currently residing in the village of Culing Centro. Sonia has been a fish vendor in their village for almost 18 years. With this business she has a net income amounting to about Php 20,000. Sometimes she's also selling pork meat for additional income. 

She wanted a loan amounting to Php 30,000 to purchase fifteen kilos of fish to sell in her village and in seven other barangays (small communities). Sonia's hoping that her requested loan will be granted so that she can improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase fifteen kilos of fish to sell.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
As a responsible mother, Merlinda engages in the buying and selling of fruits and vegetables to help her husband in supporting their family needs. She is now 53 years old and has six grown-up children. They are aiming to improve their status of living in order to prepare for a better future for their children. 

Despite financial difficulty, Merlinda has the determination to improve and strengthen the business to generate sufficient income. To improve the business, she is asking for additional capital of P30,000 to buy more stock of mustard, ampalaya leaves, onions, beans, cabbages, garlic and tomatoes to sell. She is hoping that the business will grow and become more profitable in the future.

loans.use: to buy more stock of mustard, ampalaya leaves, onions, beans, cabbages, garlic and tomatoes to sell.

location.town: Brgy. Don Mariano Perez, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios, 50 years old, is married to a jeepney driver. They are blessed with three children and they are currently residing in the village of Lalog 1. She owns and operates a transportation business (jeepney). She's been in this business for almost 16 years. Her net income monthly from the business is PHP 5,000.

She would like to avail herself of a loan amounting to PHP 10,000 to pay for the maintenance of her jeepney. She's hoping that her loan request will be granted so that she will be able to gain more income.

loans.use: To pay for the maintenance of her jeepney.

loans.name: Tuumuliaga

texts.en: Tuumuliga is a 31-year-old married woman with 5 children. She has a small plantation and grows bananas, taro, yams, etc. to earn a living. She has been doing this for 5 years. She has requested a loan to purchase weed killer, a wheelbarrow, gloves, fertilizer, and a shovel. She has been a member of SPBD since 2011. With her profits, Tuumuliga hopes to expand her business and provide more goods for people.

loans.use: to buy weed killer, a wheelbarrow, a shovel, gloves and fertilizer.

loans.name: Makerita

texts.en: Makerita is a 48-year-old married woman with 6 children. She has a small plantation and grows taro, bananas, etc. to earn a living. She has been doing this for many years. Makerita has requested a loan to help with her children's education. She has been a member of SPBD since 2011. With her profits, Makerita hopes to expand her business and help supplement her family's income.

loans.use: to pay the children's school fees, and for their school uniforms.

loans.name: Sesilia

texts.en: Sesilia is a 48-year-old married woman with 3 children. She has a small plantation and grows bananas, taro, etc. to earn a living. She has been doing this for many years. Sesilia has requested a loan to buy new equipment and supplies and also to improve her home condition. She has been a member of SPBD since 2010. With her profits, Sesilia hopes to provide her family's daily needs.

loans.use: to buy shovels, a wheelbarrow, fertilizer, gloves and weed killer.

loans.name: Cherelyn

texts.en:
Cherelyn is married with three children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. She is 30 years old and has one child who is in school.

Cherelyn has a fishing/fish vending business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 12,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase fishing materials like fishing nets, bamboo, wood, etc.

She has been in this business for 5 years. In the future, Cherelyn would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase fishing materials like fishing nets, bamboo, wood, etc.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence lives in the Nyamira area of Kenya, which is a popular banana growing region. She has five children and has been doing this work for 26 years. Her primary income sources are milk, eggs and personal business.

She stated what is most enjoyable about farming is 'quick returns on investments'. Her biggest challenge is sourcing for finances. The animals on the farm have been given the name Kitambaa. She will use the loan of 52,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow.

Florence was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied because it is cheap. This client was also asked what she learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session and she answered 'loaning process.'

Her highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked 'How will this loan benefit your family?', Florence replied that it will increase her income.

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Florence owns the following: 'cow, poultry' but does not own 'pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household 'mosquito net, solar power, TV, DVD' but does not have 'electricity, running water, sewing machine'.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en:
Cynthia is 61 years old and married with 2 children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. She has a pottery business in the Philippines and she has been in this business for 40 years. 

She requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy materials needed for her pottery. In the future, Cynthia would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy materials needed for her pottery.

loans.name: Fetu

texts.en: Fetu is a 42-year-old married woman with 6 children. She has a small plantation and grows yams, bananas, taro, etc. to earn a living. She has been doing this for many years. She has requested a loan to pay for her children's education and to buy new equipment for her business. She has been a member of SPBD since 2009. With her profits, Fetu hopes to provide her family's everyday needs.

loans.use: to buy shovels, fertilizer, weed killer, gloves, etc.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is married with four children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Helen is 46 years old and has one child who is in school. She has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines and has been in this business for 10 years.

She requested a PHP 14,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle. In the future, Helen would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle.

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Bernadette works hard to support her family.

She has a tailoring business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from raising pigs. Bernadette is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF to purchase supplies for her tailoring business.

Bernadette has been sustaining her business activities through her past 12 loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save enough money so that she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase supplies for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Mamilo Antonio

texts.en:
Mamilo Antonio is a 43-year-old seaweed farmer from the province of Bohol, Philippines. He is a married man and a father of two grown-up children. 

Mamilo Antonio hopes to expand his business but lacks the capital to do so. Mamilo Antonio is asking for a loan to buy materials for seaweed farming like seaweed seedlings, straw and rope and others. With this, he will be able to enhance his seaweed farming as well as his harvest.

loans.use: to buy materials for seaweed farming like seaweed seedlings, straw and rope.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy poultry birds.

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling used clothes in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to purchase additional used clothes to sell in her used clothing business.

Janeth has been in this business for two years. Janeth earns additional income from direct selling of Avon and MSE products and electronic re-loading.

Janeth has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional used clothes to sell.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is a 30-year-old married woman and a mother of two young children. Marilyn has been engaged in a motorcycle transport business and a sari-sari or variety store business for several years now. Marilyn is asking for a loan to buy additional groceries to sell in her store like canned goods, candies, soap and toiletries, soda, noodles and others.

In the future, Marilyn hopes to make her business a success. Moreover, she wants to save money for the schooling of her children and to repay her loan on time.

loans.use: to buy additional groceries to sell in her store like canned goods, candies, soap, toiletries, soda and noodles.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret lives in the Nyamira area of Kenya, which is a popular banana growing region. She has 5 children and has been doing this work for 25 years.  Her primary income sources are milk, eggs, tea and crops.

She stated what is most enjoyable about farming: 'Returns!' Her biggest challenge is 'Finances.' Animals on the farm have been given the names of 'Nyabarati.'

Margaret was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied: 'Convenient since loan officers visit the groups in the field.'  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: 'Loaning process requirements." She will channel the loan to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

Her highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked, 'How will this loan benefit your family?', Margaret replied 'Increase family income to meet basic needs.'

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Margaret owns the following: 'cow, poultry', but does not own 'pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household: 'mosquito net, electricity, TV, DVD', but does not have 'solar power, running water, sewing machine'.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Violet

texts.en:
Violet is a twenty-nine-year-old farmer in Kitale county in Kenya where she lives with her husband and three children who are all schooling. She has been in farming for the past eight years, producing maize, beans, milk and sweet potatoes which she sells at the local market in her area. She sells fish as an additional source of income.

She is requesting a 31,200 KES loan from Juhudi kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. She will sell the milk and earn extra income which will help her boost her family’s income and living standards, and pay for her children’s schooling. Violet aspires to have increased her dairy production in the next five years.

Diseases and the fluctuation of prices are her major challenges in farming.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Deena

texts.en:
Deena is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a pottery business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 10,000  through NWTF to buy materials for her pottery business.

Deena successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her pottery business.

NWTF is relisting Deena's business profile in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy materials for her pottery business.

loans.name: Robinson

texts.en:
Robinson is a small entreprenuer from Solana. He is 51 years old, married and has four children. His wife also helps him manage their business of selling goods to the people in their village. They have a variety store and also a farming business. The couple works untiringly to save funds for the education of their children, two of whom still attend school while the rest have already finished their degree.  

Robinson hopes to keep developing his store. He is asking for PHP 50,000 to buy cases of soft drinks, canned goods, eggs, biscuits and noodles to sell to the people in his village. It will help extend the range of good products and provide services to all their customers. 

Robinson aims to have his business progress and to generate more profit so he can give a prosperous life to his family.

loans.use: to buy cases of soft drinks, canned goods, eggs, biscuits and noodles to sell in his store.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is married to a farmer and they live happily in a rural community. Due to the hardships she faces in her daily life, she has got involved in a hog-raising business to generate additional income. She aims to make the business grow in order to have a viable source of income. 

Due to insufficient capital,  Regina is requesting an additional PHP 7,000 to buy the needed feeds and vitamins for the maintenance of her hogs. She believes that this loan will enable her to make an improvement in the business and she is hoping that she will become successful in the future.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins needed in hog-raising.

loans.name: Norah

texts.en:
Norah lives in the Nyamira area of Kenya, which is a popular banana growing region. She has 4 children and has been doing this work for 25 years.  Her primary income sources are milk, eggs, tea, crops and personal business. She will use the loan to buy and insure a dairy cow.

She stated what is most enjoyable about farming: "faster turnover on the investment!" Her biggest challenge is "finances to fund farming business." Animals on the farm have been given the names of "Maridadi."

Norah was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied: "Convenient."  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: "The loaning process."

Her highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked "How will this loan benefit your family?", Norah replied "An increase in family income."

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Norah owns the following: "cow and poultry" but does not own "pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle or automobile." Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household "mosquito net" but does not have "electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV or DVD player."

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: to buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Matauaina

texts.en:
Matauaina is 25 years old and married with 2 children. She has a small plantation where she grows yams and bananas that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for 3 years.

Matauaina needs a loan to buy equipment and tools to make her business better. She has been a member of SPBD since 2010. Matauina will use the profits from her sales to expand her business and to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to pay for fertilizers, wheelbarrow, bush knives and shovels

loans.name: Bendiya Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Bendiya sont mariées majoritairement dans des familles polygames. Elles ont en moyenne 43 ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le village de Noumou Wêrê dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles font l’achat des mortiers et des calebasses qu’elles gravent avec de beaux slogans et figures pour les revendre. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 14ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Safiatou (femme debout à l’extrême gauche sur la photo) a une grande réputation dans la vente de calebasses et de mortiers gravés  dans le village de Noumou Wêrê. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 80 calebasses et 20 mortiers, avec les foraines des villages environnants de Ségou, au marché Médine. La revente se fait au comptant  et à crédit à domicile, en ambulant et sur commande à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. Pour faire de la gravure, on met des aiguilles dans le feu pendant une heure au moins, quand elles rougissent, on l’enlève puis on fait de beaux dessins avec sur la partie externe des mortiers ou calebasses en fonction du goût de la clientèle. Madame Safiatou envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25.000 FCFA avec ce prêt, qui sera utilisé, pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et assurer le ravitaillement du foyer en condiments.
texts.en:
The 4 women of the Bendiya group are married and mainly live in polygamous family environments. They have an average age of 43 and, on average, 5 children. They all live in the village of Noumou Wêrê in the Ségou region (4th administrative region of Mali) and got to know each other thanks to neighbourly and family relationships. They buy mortars and gourds which they engrave with nice slogans and motifs and resell. The members of the group decided to work together with Soro Yiriwaso in order to increase their business and are on their 14th group loan cycle.

Safiatou (the woman standing on the far left of the photo) is well known in the village of Noumou Wêrê for her engraved mortars and gourds. She plans to use her loan to buy 80 gourds and 20 mortars from the markets in the surrounding villages of the Ségou region and at the Médine market. The sales are made for cash or credit at home, on the streets and by request, to a clientèle mostly made up of women. In order to do the engraving, needles are put in the fire for at least one hour, and when they are red hot they are taken out and used to create a nice design on the outside of the mortars or gourds, according to the customers' desires. Safiatou expects to make an average monthly profit of 25,000 francs with the help of this loan, which will be reinvested in her business and used to keep the household supplied with condiments.

loans.use: to buy gourds and mortars.

loans.name: Erdenebaatar

texts.en:
Mr. Erdenebaatar, 48 years old, lives with his wife in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The couple resides in their own house on a plot of land. His wife used to work as a driver at a transportation business entity. He himself renders transportation services between Ulaanbaatar and Darkhan, the second largest city in Mongolia. Now his wife also works as a driver at the same entity in another direction, between Ulaanbaatar and Baganuur, one of the nine districts of Ulaanbaatar but considered a separate city.

The house they live in is far away from the city center and they have difficulty accessing day-to-day activities such as shopping, transfer of cash and going to work, etc., so he is requesting a loan of 4,000,000 MNT to add to his savings for purchasing a house which is near to the city center. Over the past years he has accumulated a cash amount of 14,000,000 MNT and the price of his desired house is 18,000,000 MNT. As a result, the family can live in a strategically-located house where banks, shops and work places are easy to access. The borrower is a very hardworking individual who strives for a better future.

loans.use: to purchase a house

loans.name: Fualilia

texts.en:
Fualilia is 36 years old and married with three children. She owns and operates a small store selling items such as snacks, washing powder, rice and flour. She has been doing this for many years.

Fualilia needs a loan to buy new stock for her store. She hopes to use her profits to provide her family's needs. She became a member of SPBD in 2010 to gain access to capital for her business.

loans.use: to buy snacks, soft drinks, candies, rice and sugar

loans.name: Lida

texts.en:
As a married parent of two children, Lida works hard to support her family.

She has a tricycle transport business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from farming rice and a restaurant business. Lida is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy spare parts for her tricycle transportation.

Lida has been sustaining her business activities through her past 21 loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for her tricycle.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy poultry birds and construct a dairy unit

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Benkadi sont toutes mariées dans des familles polygames. Elles ont en moyenne 44 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le village de Noumou Were dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parenté. Elles font l’achat des mortiers et calebasses et les gravent avec de beaux slogans et figures pour les revendre. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 14ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Maïmouna (femme debout au milieu sur la photo) est connue  dans le village de Noumou Were pour la vente de calebasses et mortiers gravés de jolis dessins. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 100 calebasses  avec les foraines des villages environnants de Ségou au marché Médine. La revente se fait au comptant  et à crédit à domicile, en ambulant et sur commande à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. Pour faire de la gravure, on met des aiguilles dans le feu pendant une heure au moins, quand elles rougissent, on l’enlève puis on mentionne de beaux slogans et dessins sur la partie externe des calebasses en fonction du goût de la clientèle. Madame Maïmouna compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25.000 FCFA avec ce prêt, qui sera utilisé, pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et assurer l’entretien des enfants. Tout comme les autres membres de son groupe elle a pour objectif d’augmenter le volume de son petit commerce dans ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The 4 women of the Benkadi group are all married and live in polygamous families. They have an average age of 44 and, on average, 4 children. They all live in the village of Noumou Were in the Ségou region (4th administrative region of Mali) and got to know each other thanks to neighbourly and family relationships. They buy mortars and gourds, engrave them with nice slogans and designs, and resell them. The members of the group decided to work together with Soro Yiriwaso in order to increase their business and are on their 14th group loan cycle.

Maïmouna (the woman standing in the middle of the picture) is known in the village of Noumou Were for her mortars and gourds engraved with attractive designs. She plans to use her loan to buy 100 gourds at the markets in the surrounding villages of the Ségou region and at the Médine market. The sales are made for cash or credit at home, on the streets and by request, to a clientèle mainly composed of women. In order to do the engraving, needles are put in the fire for at least one hour and, when they are red hot, they are taken out and used to scratch nice slogans and designs on the outside of the gourds, according to the customers' tastes. Maïmouna expects to make an average monthly profit of 25 000 francs with the help of this loan, which will be reinvested in her business and used to take care of the children. As with the other members of her group, her aim is to increase the volume of her small business thanks to this partnership with Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: to buy gourds.

loans.name: Sadia's Group

texts.en:
Sadia, a 28-year-old mother of one daughter, lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan where her husband works in the private sector. Since 2010, Sadia has been running a small beauty salon out of her home.

As a member of a five-person lending group, she has requested a loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Pakistan to purchase a variety of beauty and cosmetic products for her salon including facial creams, a hair dryer, makeup kits, nail polishes, etc.

Sadia is hopeful that the loan will be a productive one. With the profit she wants to expand her business and put aside some savings for her daughter's future. She is thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of beauty and cosmetic products for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Faataualofa

texts.en:
Faataualofa is 33 years old and married with three children. She has a small plantation where she grows bananas and taro that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for three years. 

Faataualofa needs a loan to buy equipment she needs for her business, including a wheelbarrow, bush knives and fertilizers. She has been a member of SPBD since 2010. Faataualofa will use the profits from her sales to purchase land to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy a wheelbarrow, bush knives and fertilizers.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is aged 30. She is a farmer in Kitale county in Kenya, where she lives with her husband and two children, who have both started schooling. She has been in farming for the past five years, producing milk, maize, beans and eggs, which she sells at the local market in her area.

She is requesting a 52,000 KES (Kenyan shillings) loan from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow that will provide her with more milk for sale and earn her extra income, which she will use to uplift her living standards and pay for her children’s schooling. She aspires to have bought another four dairy cows in the next five years.

Diseases, fluctuation of prices and food shortages are her major challenges in farming.

She is very thankful to Juhudi Kilimo for giving her the loan.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Bolormaa

texts.en:
Mrs. Bolormaa, 29 years old, lives with her husband and two daughters in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.  The family resides in her father’s three-room apartment. Her elder daughter goes to secondary school, and her younger daughter attends a kindergarten. Her husband renders construction and outer decoration services to local people. She rents apartments to 18 households, and each one of them has made a payment contract with her.  

Over the past years, she has saved 17,000,000 MNT (Mongolian tugriks) to purchase a plot of land, but due to a lack of enough cash, she can’t afford to purchase the land fully. She is requesting a loan of 4,000,000 MNT to contribute this money for purchasing the plot of land. As a result, she can start up her new business. The land will be used for the building of a resort. The borrower is a very hardworking and calculative individual who wants to contribute to the local economic development.

loans.use: to purchase a plot of land to use for the building of a local resort to contribute to the local economic development.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James lives in the Nyamira area of Kenya, which is a popular banana growing region. He has two children and has been doing this work for 28 years.  His primary income sources are milk, eggs, tea, crops and personal business.

He stated that what is most enjoyable about farming is the returns. His biggest challenge is diseases. Animals on the farm have been given the names of Maridadi.

James was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied because it is cheap. He was also asked what he learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session and he answered 'savings management.'

His highest monthly expense is family expenses. When asked 'How will this loan benefit your family?', James replied 'Increase family income.'

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. James owns the following: 'cow, poultry' but does not own 'pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household 'mosquito net' but does not have 'electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, DVD'.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Jared

texts.en:
Jared lives in the Nyamira area of Kenya, which is a popular banana growing region. He has three children and has been doing this work for fiveyears.  His primary income sources are milk, eggs, tea, crops and personal business. He will use the loan of 50,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy a dairy cow.

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming is the harvesting season. His biggest challenge is capital financing. The animals on the farm have been given the names of 'Nyabarati.

Jared was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied 'availability of training on group management.'  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session and he answered 'savings and repayment management.'

His highest monthly expense is business-related. When asked 'How will this loan benefit your family?', Jared replied that it will increase his family income.

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Jared owns the following: 'cow, poultry' but does not own 'pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household 'mosquito net, solar power, TV, DVD' but does not have 'electricity, running water, sewing machine'.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Sarom

texts.en:
Sarom is 60 years old. She is married and resides with three children in Kampong Speu Province, Cambodia. She has been producing round bells to sell for more than 10 years, earning approximately $2 daily. Her husband is a construction worker who makes an income of $5 per day. One of her children is also a construction worker. 

Due to the difficulty with her family’s transportation, Sarom requests a loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike for commuting. This purchase will help her reduce the family's transportation expenses. In the future, she would like to expand the business and help her children earn bachelor’s degrees.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.name: Amado

texts.en:
Amado is 52 years old. married, and has three children. He is a farmer. With his income derived from planting and harvesting crops, he was able to educate his children, one of whom still attends school. Amado earns 20,000 PHP each harvest season twice a year. His wife operates a store. 

Amado is requesting a loan for 30,000 PHP, which he will use to buy farm inputs (fertilizers and insecticides). This will help nourish his rice crop to produce an abundant yield. Amado hopes to become a successful farmer and save money for emergency purposes.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs (fertilizers and insecticides).

loans.name: Sonia

texts.es: Este es su segundo financiamiento con Kiva y Sonia está muy agradecida,  porque su negocio está creciendo con este nuevo capital de trabajo, ahora tiene mas clientes y aporta mas a los gastos de su hogar y con ello mejoran todos su calidad de vida. Esta es la razón por la cual acude nuevamente a un credikiva, porque comprará materias primas para elaborar bollos, hayacas, pasteles, postres y  mercancía variada, como ropa y calzado deportivo, con lo que impactará a su clientela en la época de festividades que se acerca por motivos del Carnaval de la ciudad, donde el consumo de los productos que elabora y vende usualmente se incrementa y esto es muy bueno para impulsar los pequeños negocios. .
texts.en: This is Sonia’s second Kiva loan.  She is very grateful for the help she has received because her business is growing with this new working capital.  She now has more customers, can cover more of her household expenses and improve the quality of life of all members of her family.  For this reason, she is applying for another Kiva loan to buy raw materials to make buns, hayacas (a meat pasty wrapped in plantain leaves) and desserts, as well as a range of merchandise such as clothing and sports footwear which she will use to impress her customers during the upcoming holiday period. During the city Carnival, the demand for the goods she makes and sells tends to increase and this provides a welcome boost for small businesses.

loans.use: to buy raw materials to make buns, hayacas (a meat pasty wrapped in plantain leaves), desserts and a range of merchandise such as clothing and sports footwear

loans.name: Jelly

texts.en:
This time, for her twenty-first loan cycle, Jelly is requesting a new loan of PHP 12,000 to purchase empty sacks for her salt-making business.  

The fermented-fish-making business that she previously funded through NWTF, the Kiva field partner, continues to provide Jelly and her family with income that is improving their quality of life.

loans.use: to buy empty sacks for her salt.

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
Jacqueline is 31 years old with one child who is still in school. Jacqueline works very hard to provide for her child.

Jacqueline runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 23,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell in her general store like shampoo, groceries, etc.

Jacqueline has been in this business for seven years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, soap, and other groceries. 

In the future Jacqueline would like to save enough to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell in her general store like shampoo and groceries.

loans.name: Maritza

texts.es: Maritza, tiene la edad  de 51 años, está casada, vive con sus hijos y esposo  que son su mayor prioridad. Con su crédito pretende hacer la compra de fertilizantes, fungicidas y pagar mano de otra en trabajos de asistencia para el café. Además de poder comprar unas plantas de almácigo para realizar resiembras y así aumentar la densidad de plantas por área, además de aprovechar la buena fertilidad del suelo y las condiciones de clima y otras que favorecen al cultivo de café. Con estas mejoras al cultivo espera obtener un poco de ganancias y así mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia y también invertir un poco más en el área de cultivo y también cumplir algunas metas.  Es el primer  préstamo que  recibido de FUDECOSUR. Ella no había tenido antes otros préstamos en bancos estatales, pero FUDECOSUR le ha brindado el préstamo con mayores facilidades y la tasa de intereses mucho más baja.
texts.en:
Maritza, 51, is married.  She lives with her children and her husband, who are her main priority.

With her loan she plans to buy fertilizer and fungicide and pay for labor to help with the coffee.  She also wants to be able to buy some seedlings for replanting so she can increase the density of plants by area, as well as make the most of the good soil fertility and the climate and other conditions that favor coffee production.

With these improvements to the crop she hopes to earn some more profit so she can improve her family's living conditions, invest more in the crop, and achieve some goals.

This is her first loan from FUDECOSUR.  She hadn't had other loans in state banks, but FUDECOSUR has offered her a loan with better terms and a much lower interest rate.

loans.use: to pay for help with the coffee and planting

loans.name: Catheline

texts.en:
Catheline lives in the Nyamira area of Kenya, which is a popular banana-growing region. She has four children and has been doing farming work for ten years. Her primary income sources are milk, tea, crops, and personal business. She will use the loan to construct a dairy unit for her animals.

She stated what is most enjoyable about farming: "Returns!" Her biggest challenge is, "Finances." Animals on the farm have been given the name of 'Rex.'

Catheline was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied, "Cheap."  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi Kilimo's required microfinance training session: "Importance of loaning."

Her highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked, "How will this loan benefit your family?" Catheline replied, "Increase in family income."

As part of Juhudi Kilimo's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Catheline owns the following: 'cow, poultry', but she does not own 'pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has, in the household, 'mosquito net, TV,' but she does not have 'electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, DVD.'

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: to construct a dairy unit.

loans.name: Fokaben Group

texts.fr:
Mariées majoritairement dans des familles polygames, les quatre femmes du groupe Fokaben ont en moyenne 41 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le village de Noumou Were dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et de mariage. Elles font le commerce de calebasses et de mortiers gravés par de beaux slogans et figures. 
Dans le but de consolider leurs activités génératrices de revenu, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 14ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Aminata (femme debout à l’extrême gauche sur la photo) est une grande vendeuse de calebasses et de mortiers gravés  dans le village de Noumou Were. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 150 calebasses avec les foraines des villages environnants de Ségou au marché Médine. La revente se fait au comptant  et à crédit à domicile, en ambulant et sur commande à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. Pour faire de la gravure, on met des aiguilles dans le feu pendant une heure au moins, quand elles rougissent, on l’enlève puis on grave sur la partie externe des mortiers ou calebasses simples de belles figures en fonction du goût de la clientèle Madame Aminata compte avoir un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25.000 FCFA avec ce prêt, qui sera utilisé, pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et assurer le ravitaillement du foyer en condiments. Son objectif est de pérenniser son activité dans ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The four women who make up the Fokaben group are, for the most part, married in polygamous families. They are, on average, 41 years old and have an average of four children each. They all live in the village of Noumou Were, in the region of Ségou (4th largest administrative region in Mali). They met one another through neighborhood, family, and marital ties. They buy and sell calabashes and mortars engraved with beautiful slogans and designs.

The group members decided to start working with Soro Yiriwaso in order to help strengthen their revenue-generating activities, and they are now on their 14th group-loan cycle.

Aminata (the woman standing on the far left in the photo) is a big seller of calabashes and engraved mortars in the village of Noumou Were. She plans to use her loan to buy 150 calabashes at the Médine market from itinerant merchants from the surrounding villages in the Ségou region. She resells her goods for cash or for credit to a clientele made up mostly of women. She sells her goods from home, traveling from place to place, and she also takes orders. To make the engravings, she leaves needles in the fire for at least one hour, and when they are glowing red, she removes them and starts engraving beautiful designs on the exterior of the mortars and calabashes, according to the client's personal taste.

With the loan, Aminata expects to earn an average monthly profit of 25,000 FCFA, which she will use to reinvest in her business and provide condiments for her family. Her goal is to sustain her business through this partnership with Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: to buy calabashes

loans.name: Leticia Del Carmen

texts.es:
Leticia, se decidió por un nuevo préstamo, porque quiere comprar materia prima para elaborar más pan para la venta, ella comprar harina por mayoreo, azúcar, leña, levadura, huevos, entre otros productos que son necesarios para que ella siga realizando su trabajo.
Con el préstamo anterior ella comenta que su experiencia fue positiva, ayudándole a fortalecer más el negocio, sus condiciones en la familia se mantienen.
texts.en:
Leticia decided to get another loan because she wants to buy ingredients to make more bread to sell.  She'll buy flour in bulk, sugar, firewood, leavening, eggs, and other products she needs to continue doing her job.

She says she had a positive experience with the previous loan.  It helped her strengthen her business more.  Her family situation is the same.

loans.use: to buy sugar, firewood, leavening, and eggs

loans.name: Orlando Antonio

texts.es:
Orlando, vive con su madre y una tía, en casa familiar, no tiene hijos, él se dedica a la agricultura, aprendió desde pequeño con su padre, la agricultura y ganadería son los oficios que realiza.
Él solicita un préstamo para la compra de materiales para poder realizar una siembra, el abono y los herbicidas serán los que comprara para poder dar inicio a su trabajo, esto le ayudara a terminar de realizar el proceso en el maíz, y tener una buena producción.
Su aspiración es a futuro tener una casa propia, en el terreno.
texts.en:
Orlando lives with his mother and an aunt in the family house.  He has no children.  He makes a living in agriculture, which he learned from his father when he was young.  The work he does is agriculture and livestock.

He's requesting a loan to buy materials to be able to do the planting.  Fertilizer and herbicide are what he'll buy to be able to start his job.  This will help him finish the process with the corn and have a good crop.

His goal for the future is to have his own house on his plot of land.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and herbicide

loans.name: Melinda

texts.en:
Melinda works hard to support her family. Melinda is married and has a beauty parlor business in the Philippines.

Melinda requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to buy beauty products and other materials for her business.

Melinda has been in this business for 10 years now, and she also earns additional income from farming coconut.

In the future, Melinda would like to save enough to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy beauty products and other materials for her business.

loans.name: Faaiuga

texts.en:
Faaiuga is a 36-year-old married woman with four children.

She has a small plantation that grows taro and banana to earn a living. She has been doing this for three years. 

Faaiuga has requested a loan to expand her business.
 
She has been a member of SBPD since 2009. With her profits, Faaiuga hopes to save in her account for family needs.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, bush knifes, shovels and a wheelbarrow to expand her farm.

loans.name: Mila

texts.en:
Mila is 43 years old, married and has three children who are all in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Mila has a business that buys and sells scrap iron in the Philippines. Mila has been in this business for three years. 

Mila requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy more scrap materials to sell.

In the future, Mila would like to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more scrap materials to sell.

loans.name: Maria Sara

texts.es:
María, solicita un nuevo préstamo para seguir vendiendo meriendas, pudiendo incrementar el negocio, con este nuevo aporte comprara plátanos, yuca, azúcar, maíz y queso, estos materiales le ayudaran para seguir realizando su trabajo a los clientes.
Ella comenta que su experiencia con los préstamos anteriores fue  un ingreso mayor, ya que tenía variedad de productos, esto le ha dado mejor solvencia y considera que si ha cambiado sus ingresos.
texts.en: María is seeking a new loan to enable her to continue selling snacks and expanding her business.  With this new capital she will buy ingredients such as bananas, yucca, sugar, corn and cheese, which will enable her to continue providing her service for her customers.  She says that, after the previous loans, she experienced higher income as a result of having a range of products. Consequently, the solvency of her business improved and she believes that that is why her income has changed.

loans.use: to buy bananas, yucca, sugar, corn and cheese.

loans.name: Melagrosa

texts.en:
Melagrosa is a 56-year-old married woman and a mother of a 21-year-old daughter from Bohol, Philippines. 

Melagrosa has run a sari-sari store or convenience store business for more than 20 years now. 

Melagrosa is asking for a loan to buy more stock to sell like rice, canned goods, noodles, biscuits and snack foods. With this, she will be able to improve her store and her income.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell like rice, canned goods, noodles, biscuits and snack foods.

loans.name: Veasna

texts.en:
Veasna is 41 years old. She is married and resides with four children in Kampong Speu Province, Cambodia. 

She has been cultivating rice and fattening up animals for more than ten years, earning approximately $10 daily. Her husband is a motor taxi driver who earns about $4 per day. Two of her children are employed in a paper factory. They make an income of $6 each day. 

Due to the difficulty in her family’s transportation, Veasna requests a loan of $1,200 to purchase a motorbike for commuting. This purchase will help her reduce transportation expenses. In the future, she would like to expand her business and help her children earn bachelor’s degrees.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.name: Celia

texts.en:
This is Celia. Her previous loan was a big help in her business and she was able to buy all the products she needed for her variety store. Her loan was also a big help in the education of her children and for providing for her family's everyday expenses. Celia's variety store has been running for three years now and continues to grow. Along with her husband, a businessman, she works hard to provide income for her family's everyday expenses.

Celia is requesting another 40,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages, and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better as a greater variety will result in better profit. Celia will continue to use her business profits to help sustain her family’s daily needs and provide for her children’s education. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

In the future, Celia dreams of expanding her business as well as her husband's business. She hopes that her children will have a good life and education. Celia faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from studying the Word of God. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather weekly to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages, and other products needed in her business

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is a 51-year-old farmer in Kitale county, in Kenya, where she lives with her husband and two children who are both schooling. She has been in farming for the past ten years, producing milk, maize, and horticultural products which she sells at the local market. She owns a motorbike for transportation, as an additional source of income.

Rebecca is requesting a KES 62,400 loan from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow that will provide her with more milk for sale and earn her extra income which she will use to uplift her living standards and pay for her children’s schooling. Rebecca aspires to construct a modern dairy unit in the next five years. Diseases, high costs of production, and poor markets are her major challenges in farming.

loans.use: to buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Djèkafo Group

texts.fr:
Mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames, les cinq femmes du groupe Djèkafo ont en moyenne 26 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le village de Noumou Were dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et de mariage. 
Elles font le commerce de calebasses et de mortiers gravés de belles figures. 
Dans le but d’entreprendre une activité génératrice de revenu pour les uns et d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce pour les autres, les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er cycle de prêt solidaire. 
Madame Sanata (femme debout à l’extrême gauche sur la photo) est une grande vendeuse de calebasses et de mortiers gravés  dans le village de Noumou Were. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 10 mortiers et 60 calebasses  avec les foraines des villages environnants de Ségou, au marché Médine. La revente se fait au comptant et à crédit à domicile, en ambulant et sur commande à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. Pour faire de la gravure, on met des aiguilles dans le feu pendant une heure au moins, quand elles rougissent, on l’enlève puis on fait de beaux dessins avec sur la partie externe des calebasses ou mortiers  en fonction du goût de la clientèle. Madame Sanata espère trouver un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 17.500 FCFA avec ce prêt, qui sera utilisé, pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et assurer le ravitaillement du foyer en condiments.
texts.en:
The five members of the group Djèkafo are married women living for the most part in monogamous families. They average 26 years of age and four children each. They all live in the district of Noumou Were in the region of Segou (4th administrative region of Mali). They know one another as neighbors, and through ties of marriage and kinship. They sell finely engraved calebasses (large bowls made from dried gourds) and mortars. 

In order for some of them to launch their income-generating activity and for the others to strengthen their working capital, the group members joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. This is their first group loan cycle. 

Mrs. Sanata, standing at the far left in the photo, is a leading seller of engraved calebasses and mortars in the area of Noumou Were. She will use her loan to buy 10 mortars and 60 calebasses at the Medina market from fair-goers coming from villages surrounding Segou. 

She sells from her home, door-to-door, and on order, for cash or credit, to a clientele consisting mainly of women. 

To do the engraving, needles are placed in the fire for at least one hour until they turn red, and are then retrieved and used to make beautiful drawings on the outer surface of the calebasses or mortars based on the customer’s requirements.  

With this loan, Mrs. Sanata hopes to earn an average monthly profit of 17,500 FCFA, which she will use to reinvest in her activity and to ensure the supply of food and condiments for her household.

loans.use: to buy calebasses and mortars.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena is 49 years old and married with four children. She works hard to provide for her family. For the past 15 years, Elena has been running a general store in the Philippines and she also earns an income from raising livestock. She has borrowed and repaid eight previous loans from NWTF.

Elena is requesting a 20,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy shampoo, soap, canned goods, eggs, groceries, and other items to sell in her general store. In the future, she aspires to repair and renovate her family's home.

loans.use: to buy shampoo, soap, canned goods, eggs, groceries, and other items to sell in her general store

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Sorn is 41 years old. She is married and resides with her three children in Kampong Speu Province, Cambodia. She is a housekeeper. Her husband is a construction worker who earns about $7 daily. Two of her children are employed in a garment factory. They make an income of $7 per day. 

Due to lack of funds, Sorn is requesting a loan of $1,500 to purchase metal to build a handrail for the stairs in her house. In the future, she would like to run a grocery store at home to generate more income to financially support the family. Moreover, she wants her youngest child to earn a bachelor’s degree.

loans.use: to purchase metal to build a stair handrail in her house

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a 47-year-old married man living in Masindi, Uganda. He sells fish in different markets and with the proceeds he has been able to pay school fees for his children and renovate his house. Lack of refrigeration equipment and inadequate capital to purchase in bulk hinders his business profits, while his dream is to buy a refrigerated van. John intends to use the loan to buy fish to sell.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell.

loans.name: Victor

texts.en: Victor is a farmer who is raising his family in a rural community. Despite financial difficulty, he has the determination to uplift their poor living status to give his family a better life. He engages in a hog-raising business to earn additional income. Victor planned to raise more pigs to sell but he doesn't have enough capital. Therefore, he is asking for an additional 10,000 PHP to buy feed, vitamins and additional piglets to raise. Through hard work and perseverance, Victor believes that he will make the business viable and profitable in the future.

loans.use: to buy feed, vitamins and additional piglets to raise

loans.name: Huma's Group

texts.en:
Huma is 39 years old and married with three children, all of whom are students. She lives in a remote area of Rawalpindi, Pakistan, with her family. Huma's husband is a photographer and she is an efficient beautician.  

Huma is requesting a loan to purchase some cosmetic products and furniture for her salon. She will purchase chairs, makeup kits, nail polish, a hair dryer, and a variety of creams. Huma is thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan and is sure to return her loan on time. In the future, she hopes to open a beautician center.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of cosmetic products and furniture for her beauty salon

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy is 28 years old, married and blessed with three children, ages 10, 8 and 3 years, that she supports. She has been running a charcoal business for the last five years making a monthly income of 12,000 KES.

This is her first loan of 10,000 KES from KADET LTD. She plans to purchase more charcoal for sale. The anticipated income will open another stall for charcoal. Her future dream is to expand the business.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a buy and sell lobster business in the Philippines. Teresa has been in this business for 20 years. She earns more income from fish vending.

Teresa is borrowing 29,500 PHP through NWTF to purchase more lobsters to sell. She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: purchase more lobsters to sell

loans.name: Salina

texts.en:
Salina is a 31-year-old farmer in Kitale county in Kenya where she lives with her husband and three children who are all schooling. Salina has been in farming for the past 15 years producing maize, beans, milk and poultry products which she sells at the local market in her area. She runs a mini-retail shop as an additional source of income.

Salina is requesting a 31,200 KES loan from Juhudi kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. She will sell the milk and earn extra income which will help boost her family’s income and living standards. She will use some of the money to pay for her children’s schooling. Salina aspires to purchase two more dairy cows and expand her farm in the next five years.

Diseases, unreliable rainfall and fluctuation of prices are her major challenges in farming.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.name: Helen's Group

texts.en:
Helen is a young Iraqi woman and leader of Helen's Group. She is 23 years old and married. With limited career options due to cultural restrictions and domestic constraints, Helen is one of the many Iraqi women who are working from home, using their sewing skills to generate some income and participate in meeting the financial needs of their families.

Helen has five years' experience with sewing and tailoring and would like to improve the services she can offer to her customers. One of her priorities is to replace her old sewing machine with a newer model. To be able to do more creative jobs, she would also like to buy an over machine and nice, quality fabrics and raw materials to work with. To be able to make these purchases, she took a loan from Relief International Microfinance Iraq.

Relief International Microfinance Iraq offers "Group loans" for clients unable to provide a guarantor - thereby unable to apply for a loan as an individual. As a group, the members collectively guarantee the loan. Groups consist of three to five clients and each client is evaluated on his or her repayment capacity. All group members receive the same loan amount as the individual with the lowest repayment capacity in the group.
